1.learning_goal: Web Pages in Motion: In this unit, students will learn how the web works end-to-end—distinguishing user, browser (client), and server roles; tracing requests, responses, URLs, and paths; and building simple multi-page HTML sites using correct elements, tags, attributes, and links.

chapters.title: How the Web Talks
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how browsers (clients) and servers work together to load a web page, what each one is responsible for, and what it means to “serve” different kinds of files like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and images.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Browser and Client
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define browser and client in a web page scenario; Describe what the browser does with HTML/CSS/JS at a high level; Identify what the user controls vs what the browser controls

lessons.title: Server and Response
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define server and response; List common response files (HTML, CSS, JS, images); Understand what it means to “serve a file”

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Web roles in a cafe website
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to clearly distinguish between the browser (client) and the server, and explain what each one does when loading a simple cafe website. Output: A completed answer sheet where each action in the story is correctly labeled as “user,” “browser,” or “server,” plus short written explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Serving files for a photo gallery
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to identify common response file types and explain what it means for a server to “serve” each file to a browser. Output: A filled-in mapping exercise that matches file types (HTML, CSS, JS, images) to their roles and a step-by-step description of how a server responds to a gallery page request.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: How Web Requests Work
chapters.learning_goals: Understand what happens when you load a page or resource in the browser, how URLs and paths control what gets requested, and what occurs when those requests fail—so you can read, trace, and debug simple web request/response flows.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Request in Plain Words
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define request using everyday examples (page load, image load); Trace “type URL → request → response → render”; Predict what happens when a request fails (missing page/file)

lessons.title: URLs and Paths
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify URL parts: domain + path + query (conceptually); Distinguish URL path vs local file path; Understand why correct paths matter for loading resources

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Request journey for a news article
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to trace the full “type URL → request → response → render” flow and predict what happens when a request fails. Output: A diagram or ordered list that correctly sequences each step of the request/response process with annotations for success and failure cases.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: URL and path detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to break down URLs into domain, path, and query and distinguish URL paths from local file paths in practical scenarios. Output: A completed worksheet where several sample URLs and file paths are analyzed, labeled, and corrected to ensure resources load correctly.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building Your First HTML Pages
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how HTML structures a page, how to use common elements and tags (including self-closing tags), and practice by building simple, well-structured pages like a personal bio and a story outline.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: HTML Elements
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define HTML as page structure; Create a page using common elements (h1, p, a); Use headings to create a readable structure

lessons.title: HTML Elements vs Tags
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand difference between elements and tags; Identify and understand the opening and closing tag; Identify and understand self-closing tags

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Personal bio page
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to structure a simple HTML page using headings, paragraphs, and links to create a readable personal bio. Output: A basic HTML file that displays a personal bio with a clear heading hierarchy and at least one working link.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Story outline page
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to use HTML elements and tags correctly, including opening, closing, and self-closing tags, to build a short story outline page. Output: An HTML file that shows a story title, sections using headings and paragraphs, and at least one self-closing tag (like an image or line break) used correctly.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Links and HTML Attributes
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to use common HTML attributes (like href, src, and alt) and how attribute values affect content, then apply them to build and debug working internal and external links between a small set of pages.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: HTML Attributes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify an attribute as name="value" on a tag; Use common attributes correctly (href, src, alt); Understand what “value” means in an attribute context

lessons.title: Links Between Pages
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create links between index.html and about.html; Use relative paths correctly; Debug a broken link by fixing the path; Understand the difference between internal and external links

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Two-page portfolio - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to use common HTML attributes (href, src, alt) correctly and understand how attribute values affect how content appears and behaves. Output: An HTML page that shows a profile image with alt text and several links using correctly formed attributes and values.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Two-page portfolio - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to create working internal and external links between pages using relative paths and debug broken links by fixing incorrect paths. Output: A small two-page site (index.html and about.html) with links that successfully navigate between the pages and to at least one external site.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

2.learning_goal: Semantic Pages & Forms: In this unit, students will build small multi-page sites with clear semantic structure, meaningful headings and lists, and basic forms wired with labels, IDs, and names so they understand how browsers load pages and conceptually send user input as data.

chapters.title: Building Semantic Web Pages
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to structure content with semantic HTML, create a simple multi-page site with consistent navigation, and practice organizing real-world pages (like a cafe homepage and a portfolio) into clear, meaningful sections.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Semantic Page Layout
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a page with header, nav, main, section, footer; Understand what semantic HTML means (simple definition); Organize content into clear sections (not random divs)

lessons.title: Three Pages, One Site
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create index.html, about.html, contact.html; Keep navigation consistent across pages; Understand how the browser loads different pages via links

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe homepage layout
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice building a single-page cafe homepage using semantic HTML elements (header, nav, main, section, footer) to organize content clearly. Output: A simple static cafe homepage that displays clearly separated areas for branding, navigation, content, and footer information.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Three-page portfolio site
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create index.html, about.html, and contact.html with consistent navigation to understand how a small multi-page site works. Output: A basic three-page portfolio website where clicking navigation links moves between the pages in the browser.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Headings and Lists That Work
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to structure pages with clear heading hierarchies and meaningful lists so content is easier to read, scan, and navigate. Practice by building a blog article layout and a restaurant menu that use headings and lists effectively.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Headings That Make Sense
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use one h1 per page and structure sections with h2; Fix a page with messy heading levels; Understand why hierarchy matters for readability

lessons.title: Lists for Real Content
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use ul/ol/li for actual content (menu items, steps, features); Choose the right list type for the purpose; Combine lists with links for simple navigation patterns

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Blog article structure
lessons.learning_outcomes: Structure a blog article page using one h1 and meaningful h2 subheadings to create a clear, readable hierarchy. Output: A static blog article page whose headings visually and logically separate the content into well-defined sections.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Restaurant menu with lists
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a restaurant menu using unordered and ordered lists, choosing appropriate list types and combining them with links for simple navigation. Output: A static restaurant menu page where dishes and sections are presented as lists, with a small in-page navigation list linking to different menu sections.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Structuring Pages and Forms
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to group page content with divs for clear layout, and build simple sign-up forms using common input types and placeholders—while using Q&A time to clarify concepts and solidify your understanding.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Clean Sections with Divs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use div to group content when semantics don’t fit; Add classes to divs to label page sections; Keep a layout readable using consistent grouping

lessons.title: Form Inputs and Values
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define input and value in plain terms (the HTML element vs what the user types); Use common input types (text, email, password) and understand what changes; Add and explain the placeholder attribute (hint text, not the actual value)

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Landing page sections with divs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group related content into clearly labeled divs with classes to keep a simple landing page’s layout readable when semantic tags don’t quite fit. Output: A static landing page where content blocks (hero, features, testimonials, footer area) are grouped in divs with meaningful class names for easy visual scanning.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Simple sign-up form
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a basic sign-up form using text, email, and password inputs, and use placeholders to guide what users should type. Output: A static sign-up form that shows different input behaviors by type and displays hint text inside each field before the user types.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building Reliable HTML Forms
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to connect labels and inputs correctly, group fields into forms, and use `id`, `for`, and `name` attributes so that form data is clear, predictable, and ready to be submitted.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Labels and IDs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add a label for each input and understand why labels exist; Connect label to input using for + id; Fix a broken page where clicking the label focuses the wrong input

lessons.title: Forms and Input Names
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap inputs in a form and understand what “submit” means at a high level; Add the name attribute and understand why it matters for submission; Predict the “data keys” a form will send based on input names

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Contact form labels and IDs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add labels to each input in a contact form and correctly connect them with for and id so clicking labels focuses the right input. Output: A static contact form where every field has a clickable label that activates the correct input box.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Feedback form submission basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap inputs in a form, add name attributes, and predict the key–value pairs that would be sent when the form is submitted. Output: A static feedback form that, when “submitted,” would conceptually send labeled data (using the input names) for each field the user filled in.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

3.learning_goal: HTML & CSS Foundations: In this unit, students will write clean, well-structured, and accessible HTML, apply basic CSS through multiple methods (inline, internal, external), and use core layout concepts like selectors, text styling, visual sections, the box model, and display types to build and debug simple, readable web pages.

chapters.title: Clean, Accessible HTML
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to write well-structured, readable HTML and apply basic accessibility habits using semantic landmarks, alt text, and labels. Practice these skills by cleaning up an existing page and building a simple, accessible landing page from scratch.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: HTML Quality Habits
lessons.learning_outcomes: Keep HTML consistently indented and readable; Spot and fix broken nesting and missing closing tags; Use DevTools Elements tab to confirm structure

lessons.title: Basic Accessibility Habits
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use semantic landmarks (nav, main) intentionally; Add alt text and proper labels reliably; Identify 2-3 easy accessibility improvements on a page

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe homepage cleanup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Improve an existing cafe HTML page by fixing indentation, broken nesting, missing closing tags, and verifying structure with DevTools. Output: A cleaned-up, well-indented cafe homepage where all elements are correctly nested and visible in the DevTools Elements tree.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Accessible music app landing page
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a simple music app landing page using semantic landmarks, descriptive alt text, and proper labels while spotting 2–3 accessibility improvements. Output: An HTML page for a music app that uses nav/main/footer, labeled form controls, and accessible images.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: CSS Basics in Action
chapters.learning_goals: Learn the three main ways to add CSS to a page and how to target elements with tag, class, and ID selectors, then apply them in small projects like a to‑do list and recipe card while getting feedback and asking questions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: CSS: Three Ways
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply CSS inline (style="") for quick tests; Apply CSS in a <style> tag for page-level styling; Link an external CSS file with <link> for reuse

lessons.title: Selectors: Tag, Class, ID
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write selectors using tag, class, and id; Predict which elements a selector targets; Fix a selector that styles the wrong elements

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do list styles – inline and style tag
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style a simple to-do list page using inline styles for quick tests and a <style> tag for page-level styling while predicting which elements each rule affects. Output: A to-do list HTML page where items are visually differentiated using inline and internal CSS rules.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Recipe card with tag, class, and ID selectors
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a recipe card layout and apply tag, class, and ID selectors to style different parts, then fix a selector that targets the wrong elements. Output: A recipe card page where headings, ingredients, and steps are styled correctly via external CSS using precise selectors.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Consistent Text and Page Sections
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to style text and divs with reusable CSS so your headings, paragraphs, and visual sections look clear, consistent, and easy to read across a full page.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Styling Text Tags
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style headings and paragraphs (size, spacing, alignment); Improve readability with consistent text styling; Keep styles consistent across multiple pages

lessons.title: Divs and Visual Blocks
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style div sections using background, padding, borders; Create clear sections of a page using CSS; Use classes to apply the same styling pattern repeatedly

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Blog teaser text styling
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design a simple blog teaser page by styling headings and paragraphs for size, spacing, and alignment, keeping text styles consistent across multiple sections. Output: A blog-style page with multiple article previews whose titles and body text share a consistent, readable text styling pattern.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Portfolio sections with visual blocks
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a one-page portfolio using divs as visual sections, styled with background colors, padding, borders, and reusable classes for repeated section patterns. Output: A portfolio page where each section (about, projects, contact) appears as a clearly separated visual block using shared CSS classes.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Box Model and Inline Layout
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to control spacing with the CSS box model and distinguish block, inline, and inline-block behavior. Practice building a product card and navigation bar while using DevTools to inspect margins, padding, and layout issues in real time.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Box Model Spacing
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply margin vs padding intentionally; Understand spacing using box model vocabulary; Use DevTools to inspect margin and padding live

lessons.title: Block vs Inline
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish block vs inline behavior; Use display: inline-block for simple layout needs; Debug “why won’t these sit next to each other?” issues

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Product card spacing with box model
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a product card layout and intentionally adjust margin and padding while using DevTools to inspect and understand the box model spacing. Output: A product card component where image, title, price, and button are spaced clearly using well-tuned margins and padding.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Navigation bar layout – block vs inline
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a simple navigation bar and experiment with block, inline, and inline-block display values to place items side by side and debug spacing issues. Output: A horizontal navigation bar where menu links sit next to each other using display properties to control their layout.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

4.learning_goal: Interactive Pages in Action: In this unit, students style reusable buttons and inputs, debug CSS with DevTools, then add JavaScript-driven behavior by selecting DOM elements, handling events like clicks and submits, updating text, and toggling visibility and color themes to build responsive, interactive web pages.

chapters.title: Buttons, Inputs, and Debugging
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to style buttons and form inputs consistently with reusable CSS classes, including hover and focus states, and use browser DevTools to trace, debug, and fix CSS issues in real projects.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Buttons and Inputs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style buttons with hover and focus states (basic usability); Style inputs for consistent form design; Keep button and input styles reusable via classes

lessons.title: CSS Debugging in DevTools
lessons.learning_outcomes: Find where a style is coming from in the Styles panel; Identify why a style isn’t applying (wrong selector or wrong file); Make a test change in DevTools, then apply it in code

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe order form
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style buttons and inputs consistently using reusable classes, including hover and focus states, and use DevTools to trace and fix style issues. Output: A styled cafe order form where buttons and inputs look consistent and react visually on hover/focus.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Bug hunt in signup form
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use the browser DevTools Styles panel to locate where styles come from, identify why certain styles are not applying, and then fix them in the CSS file. Output: A corrected signup form whose buttons and inputs now match the intended design after debugging CSS issues.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: JavaScript on Real Web Pages
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how JavaScript adds behavior to otherwise static pages, how to correctly link and run scripts, and how to use the DOM and `querySelector` to find and store elements for later interaction.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: JavaScript Adds Behavior
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand what JavaScript is used for on a web page; Link a script.js file correctly; Use console.log to confirm the script runs

lessons.title: DOM: Find Elements
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DOM in practical terms (page structure JS can access); Select elements with querySelector; Store elements in variables for reuse

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Console-based welcome page
lessons.learning_outcomes: Correctly link an external JavaScript file, verify it runs with console.log, and explain how JavaScript adds behavior to an otherwise static page. Output: A simple webpage that logs personalized welcome messages to the browser console when loaded.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music playlist highlighter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use the DOM and querySelector to find specific elements on the page, store them in variables, and prepare them for later interactive behavior. Output: A static music playlist page where specific song items are selected via JavaScript and visually highlighted using added classes or inline styles.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Events and Interactive Pages
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how browser events work and how to use them to update the DOM, from simple clicks to form submissions. Practice wiring up buttons and forms so pages respond to user actions with clear, readable JavaScript.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Events: Click and Submit
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define an event (click, submit, input); Attach event listeners and run a function; Debug “event not firing” using console logs

lessons.title: Change Text on Click
lessons.learning_outcomes: Update text content of an element on click; Understand what changed in the DOM (content changed); Keep logic small and readable (one clear function)

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Click counter button
lessons.learning_outcomes: Attach click event listeners to a button, debug event issues with console logs, and update text content in the DOM every time the button is clicked. Output: A page with a button that shows and updates a click count in text each time it is pressed.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Mini feedback form
lessons.learning_outcomes: Listen for a form submit event, run a small readable function, prevent default submission, and change a thank-you message’s text content based on the input. Output: A feedback form that, on submit, shows a custom thank-you message on the page without reloading.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Toggling Content and Themes
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to show and hide page content with JavaScript, track simple UI state with booleans, and update button text to match what the interface is doing. Practice building FAQ toggles and a dark/light reading mode by changing styles from JavaScript while keeping behavior predictable and reversible.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Show and Hide Content
lessons.learning_outcomes: Show and hide an element using style.display; Track simple state using a boolean variable; Update button text based on current state

lessons.title: Toggle Page Colors
lessons.learning_outcomes: Change background and text colors from JS; Understand the difference between CSS styling and JS-driven styling; Keep dark/light behavior predictable and reversible

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: FAQ answer toggler
lessons.learning_outcomes: Show and hide FAQ answers using style.display, track visibility with a boolean, and update the toggle button text to match the current state. Output: An FAQ section where clicking a button reveals or hides an answer while the button label switches between “Show answer” and “Hide answer.”

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Reading mode color toggle
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a dark/light mode toggle using JavaScript-driven styling, keeping the color changes predictable, reversible, and clearly separated from base CSS. Output: A page with a “Toggle reading mode” button that switches the background and text colors between light and dark themes.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions
